column2: A33-year-old woman in El Salvador who suffered a medical emergency while pregnant has been freed after serving a decade in jail for attempted murder, the victim of a draconian abortion ban being replicated in the US. The woman, named only as Jacqueline, sought medical help for an obstetric complication in 2011, and even though the baby survived, she was arrested on suspicion of attempted abortion. She was separated from her newborn daughter and eight-year-old son, and sentenced to 15 years for attempted murder. Jacqueline, who was released on Wednesday, is the 65th woman to be freed having been wrongly jailed on murder charges following a miscarriage or other obstetric emergency since the total ban on abortion came into force in 1998. The Salvadorian anti-abortion law, which was subsequently written into the constitution, has led to at least 182 women who suffered an obstetric emergency being prosecuted for abortion or aggravated homicide. Poor, young, women from rural areas with limited access to healthcare have been disproportionately persecuted, with most reported to the police by hospital workers. In many cases, prosecutors and judges have argued that the womanâ€™s failure to save the pregnancy amounted to murder. Salvadorian lawyers and activists have worked to free the convicted women, pursuing pardons, sentence reduction and access to education and work programs that can lead to an early release. Ten women have been freed since last December, leaving three still in prison. Each case has taken a sustained campaign of protests, public health efforts and media pressure, according to Morena Herrera, a reproductive rights campaigner who recalls the moment when lawmakers, spurred on by the religious right, voted to ban abortion without exception in April 1997. â€œI warned them that this law would end the presumption of innocence for pregnant women, which is exactly what happened. Itâ€™s this same risk that the US is now facing,â€ said Herrera. A leaked supreme court decision suggests that Roe vs Wade â€“ the 1973 ruling which guarantees the right to abortion â€“ will soon be overturned, resulting in about half of US states banning or severely restricting access to safe legal abortion. Texas and Oklahoma have already approved severe restrictions. Herrera added: â€œDonâ€™t let our reality become your reality. If the law changes, doctorsâ€™ hands will be tied and women will die. Do everything you can to stop this because the consequences of losing access to abortion are grave.â€ In El Salvador, a country of 6.5 million people, the consequences include death for women with ectopic pregnancies who have been denied timely medical care. Many others have suffered complications to their physical and mental health. Suicide rates among young pregnant women have risen. Last week advocates were dismayed when Esme, a 28-year-old from a poor rural community, was sentenced to 30 years for aggravated homicide after suffering a miscarriage â€“ the first woman convicted for an obstetric complication in seven years. â€œWe are in shock, maybe we didnâ€™t put enough pressure. You can never take your foot off the pedal,â€ said Paula Ãvila-GuillÃ©n, a human rights lawyer and executive director of the New York-based Womenâ€™s Equality Centre. Esme spent two years in jail on remand, but is currently at home while lawyers appeal the verdict. The battle to free the three other women continues. MarÃ­a del Rosario was 23 years old when she started haemorrhaging at home alone. Instead of receiving medical help, she was detained by police and sentenced to 30 years for aggravated homicide (later reduced to 20 years). MarÃ­a del Rosarioâ€™s pregnancy was the result of rape; her alleged aggressor was acquitted. She has spent a decade in prison. Liliana was a 21-year-old mother expecting her second baby in 2016 when she was sentenced to 30 years in jail for homicide after suffering a medical emergency. The sentence was later halved, but she has already spent seven years separated from her daughter. The case of Bertha Arana is especially egregious. Arana, 28, was convicted of attempted murder in 2012 after suffering a medical emergency, even though her daughter survived. But unlike Jacqueline, every attempt to secure a reduction in her 30-year sentence has been blocked because Arana was born just over the border in Guatemala and does not have Salvadorian identity papers. She has not seen her daughter since giving birth. â€œBerthaâ€™s case is not just unjust, itâ€™s cruel,â€ said Herrera. The UN has condemned such cases as arbitrary detentions. As the US contemplates the reality of a post-Roe world, the Salvadorian experience demonstrates the long-term impact on women who are criminalised. Cristina Quintanilla was 18 and excited about motherhood when she suffered a late miscarriage in 2005. She woke up handcuffed to a hospital bed, and was given 30 years for aggravated murder, though was released after serving four after a sentence review. Vilified as a â€œbaby killerâ€ in El Salvador, Quintanilla was unable to find work and in 2014 made it to the US where she sought asylum. Sheâ€™s been in legal limbo ever since, waiting for an immigration judge to rule on the case, but was denied a work visa because of her criminal record. â€œThe injustice continues, I canâ€™t escape it. Iâ€™m so tired of fighting to clear my name, to be given an opportunity to live my life,â€ said Quintanilla, 36. â€œItâ€™s very unfortunate whatâ€™s happening here. Americans face a very uncertain future, it will be chaos.â€ The US backslide comes amid a wave of legal and political reproductive rights victories across Latin America improving access to safe abortion from women in countries such as Mexico, Colombia, Chile and Argentina. Ãvila-GuillÃ©n, who works with lawyers and activists across Latin America, said they had learned lessons from the erosion of abortion rights in the US. â€œWe realised that human rights standards and legal strategy would never be enough, we also needed mass mobilizations, activism, political work and a communication strategy, and thatâ€™s what the US will need to do to win hearts and minds and get our rights back.â€

column2: It was little more than a year ago that US officials were publicly rubbishing the prospect of engagement with Venezuelaâ€™s President NicolÃ¡s Maduro, who they described as a â€œdictatorâ€. â€œHis repression, corruption and mismanagement have generated one of the most dire humanitarian crises this hemisphere has seen,â€ the state department spokesperson, Ned Price, declared in February 2021. â€œWe certainly donâ€™t expect any contact with Maduro anytime soon.â€ Yet 2022 appears to have heralded a new dawn for Washington-Caracas ties, as geopolitical shifts caused by Russiaâ€™s invasion of Ukraine and political deadlock in the economically devastated South American country prompt a major policy rethink from members of Joe Bidenâ€™s administration â€“ and offer Venezuelaâ€™s authoritarian leader a once improbable political lifeline. On Tuesday, the US announced a gentle easing of the economic sanctions it has spent years using to push for political change in Venezuela â€“ including against a nephew of its first lady â€“ a move senior members of Maduroâ€™s government celebrated. â€œVenezuela hopes that these decisions by the United States of America will pave the way to the total lifting of the illegal sanctions which affect our entire people,â€ the countryâ€™s vice-president, Delcy RodrÃ­guez, tweeted in English as the news emerged. Simultaneously, her brother, another top Chavista called Jorge RodrÃ­guez, shared a photograph of himself shaking hands with the chief negotiator for Venezuelaâ€™s opposition, Gerardo Blyde, signalling the reactivation of stalled talks designed to bridge the countryâ€™s toxic political schism. â€œCongratulations!â€ tweeted Marcelo Ebrard, the foreign minister of Mexico, where those negotiations were happening until their suspension last October after the extradition of the Maduro ally Alex Saab to the US. Some see Washingtonâ€™s change of heart as a direct consequence of Vladimir Putinâ€™s war against Ukraine. In March, days after Russiaâ€™s onslaught began, senior US officials flew to Caracas for their first encounter with Maduro representatives in years. That visit was partly motivated by a US desire to increase oil production in Venezuela â€“ which boasts the worldâ€™s largest proven reserves â€“ in order to restrain global oil prices, which have soared as a result of Putinâ€™s war. Christopher Sabatini, a Chatham House Latin America expert, said the war in Ukraine had also prompted a rethink in Caracas, which desperately needed new markets for its oil as well as access to western refineries, banking systems and investment. â€œItâ€™s true that oil prices have gone up with Russiaâ€™s invasion of Ukraine but, because of sanctions, Russia is now increasing the sale of its oil to China, which was Venezuelaâ€™s principal market,â€ he added. Yet Sabatini believed Washingtonâ€™s shift had been planned well before Putinâ€™s invasion and reflected the USâ€™s realization that the Trump-era â€œmaximum pressureâ€ policy â€“ by which harsh sanctions were used to try to topple Maduro and replace him with the young opposition leader Juan GuaidÃ³ â€“ had failed. â€œIt is a demonstration that the US and much of the international community bet on a solution that simply hasnâ€™t worked,â€ Sabatini said. â€œThatâ€™s anathema to some people in the US Congress. Itâ€™s anathema to some elements of the Venezuelan opposition who always hoped and dreamed for some sort of cathartic collapse of the government and the fleeing of Maduro and his cronies. But clearly Maduro has hung on, [albeit] at a huge cost to his country â€¦ and now the US has to [engage].â€ Representatives of Venezuelaâ€™s mainstream opposition, and the rival government GuaidÃ³ created when his campaign to unseat Maduro started in January 2019, now accept dealing with their foe is the only way forwards as the country heads towards its next scheduled presidential election in 2024. Speaking to the Guardian during a recent tour of Europe, GuaidÃ³â€™s deputy foreign minister, Isadora Zubillaga, admitted: â€œThe reality is that we must talk. We were not able to wipe them out and they were not able to wipe us out either. That negotiation process must include discussion of the lifting of sanctions and penalties.â€ However, Zubillaga warned the west against boosting what she called a Putin-led autocratic coalition by offering too many concessions to Maduro. â€œThe Maduro regime is sustained by the international alliance, including countries like Iran, Russia, Cuba and China. If Maduro is helped, so is Putin,â€ Zubillaga said. A senior US administration official said that it would calibrate its sanctions policy depending on the behaviour of Maduroâ€™s administration and whether â€œambitious, concrete and irreversibleâ€ steps towards free and democratic elections were achieved at talks. Members of the US right denounced the loosening of sanctions, which include allowing limited contact between the US oil giant Chevron and Venezuelaâ€™s government. â€œBiden continues his effort to appease anti-American communist dictators,â€ tweeted the Republican senator Marco Rubio, one of the cheerleaders for Trumpâ€™s bungled anti-Maduro drive. A Wall Street Journal editorial slammed Bidenâ€™s â€œdance with a Latin dictatorâ€. Others expressed cautious optimism that, while there would be no overnight solutions to Venezuelaâ€™s profound economic, humanitarian and political crises, the return of negotiations â€“ and incentives for Maduro and others around him to offer concessions â€“ was a step towards a democratic transition. Geoff Ramsey, the director for Venezuela at the Washington Office on Latin America, said: â€œThe only feasible transition is a pacted transition which is going to require some level of negotiations with political, military and economic elites. â€œWhat we are seeing is a recognition of that reality. I donâ€™t think that means that the US or other actors of the international community are ignorant or naive about the difficulties that lie ahead,â€ he added. â€œIf the problem in Venezuela were simply a lack of dialogue we would have seen the crisis solved years ago.â€
column4: Maduro glimpses political lifeline as US rethinks Venezuela policy

column2: Royal Mail has warned that the company is at a â€œcrossroadsâ€ and needs to urgently adapt to the post-pandemic environment as parcel deliveries, originally boosted by Covid lockdowns, continue to wane. It piles further pressure on the postal company, as it struggles to reach a pay deal with unionised staff who are pushing for an inflation-based pay rise as the cost of living soars. Royal Mail said on Thursday it suffered an 8.8% drop in annual pre-tax profits to Â£662m, explaining that revenues were flat as the easing of Covid restrictions reduced demand for parcel deliveries. The drop was partially offset by the distribution of Covid test kits, but overall, parcel demand across the UK fell 7% year-on-year. Chairman Keith Williams admitted that the financial tailwinds of the pandemic â€œare now dissipatingâ€ and that the company was steeling itself for a drop in economic growth and higher inflation that could pose challenges for both its UK and international delivery business. â€œWe are at a crossroads with the transformation of Royal Mail,â€ he said. â€œWe need to adapt our business to a post-pandemic world and whilst we are making progress in some areas, more needs to be done in othersâ€. The news sent shares down nearly 10% on Thursday morning, wiping nearly Â£400m off the companyâ€™s value and making Royal Mail the biggest faller on the FTSE 100. The courier also faces an ongoing pay claim with staff represented by the Communication Workers Union (CWU), which said Royal Mailâ€™s full-year profits were â€œearned off the backs of our members hard workâ€. However, the union is understood to be seeking an inflation-based pay rise with â€œno strings attachedâ€. Figures released on Wednesday showed that UK inflation hit 9% in April, its highest level for more than 40 years, following a surge in food, energy and transport costs. A Royal Mail spokesperson said it wanted to reach an agreement with the CWU as soon as possible. â€œOur industry is characterised by a race to the bottom on pay and terms and conditions. We will not join that race and will retain our place as the industry leader on pay and terms and conditions. We value the work we do with CWU and remain committed to agreeing a deal.â€

column2: As the libel suit between Rebekah Vardy and Coleen Rooney rumbles on in the high court, the public has heard weeks of claims and counterclaims about Instagram stings, paparazzi ambushes and phones lost in the sea. But one thing has been clear from the outset: one of the two women has been betrayed. Either, as Rooney claims, Vardy sold stories about her fellow Wag to the Sun, or, as Vardy maintains, Rooneyâ€™s baseless accusation has dragged her good name through the mud. It is a messy and sordid tale from which no one â€“ except possibly the lawyers â€“ emerges the better. Rooney has described Vardyâ€™s WhatsApp exchanges about her as â€œevilâ€; Vardy has said that the threats and abuse she received after Rooneyâ€™s accusations made her feel suicidal. What is driving the former friends to spend millions airing their most intimate details? Betrayal by a friend is not something you can just laugh off, says Dr Jennifer Freyd, a psychology professor at the University of Oregon. â€œThe very place where you should be able to get help and protection from the harms of life becomes the source of harm.â€ She coined the term â€œbetrayal traumaâ€ to describe the pain such treachery can cause. â€œWe are a social species; when someone betrays us, itâ€™s a real threat to our wellbeing.â€ There are degrees of betrayal, of course. Most of us will have experienced a friend gossiping uncharitably behind our backs, for example â€“ or perhaps we have been that friend. This is hardly Judas kissing Jesus in the Garden of Gethsemane. â€œBut what we find overall is that betrayal is toxic,â€ Freyd says. â€œPeople who are betrayed are likely to have physical and mental health challenges.â€ Annabel, who is in her 50s and lives in Wales, was betrayed by her former friend Jane. They met in the early 2000s. Annabel ran a specialist business at a food market; Jane visited her stand often and befriended her at a marketing event. â€œWe just clicked,â€ says Annabel. â€œShe was really friendly. Weâ€™d go to each otherâ€™s houses for meals.â€ Annabel introduced Jane to her friends and gave her work on her stall, teaching her all about her business. Jane then announced that she planned to set up a rival stand, selling the same products at the same market. Annabel was horrified. â€œI told her that I was hurt and I thought it would be awkward and strange for other people,â€ says Annabel. â€œIt didnâ€™t work personally and from a business point of view we were going to be sharing customers.â€ Jane was unmoved, even suggesting that, if Annabel was unhappy, she might like to consider moving markets. Just like that, their friendship was over. At first, Janeâ€™s stand didnâ€™t affect Annabelâ€™s sales too greatly, but over time her income declined. â€œThe market could not sustain two similar businesses,â€ she says. Eventually, Annabel left. The experience made her feel â€œvery lonely â€“ like I couldnâ€™t trust anyone. I felt that people might just be after what I had got.â€ She was, she says, â€œupset for a very long timeâ€. This is a common response to feelings of betrayal, says Holly Roberts, a psychotherapist with the relationship charity Relate. â€œWhen you open up to a friend, you make yourself vulnerable to that person,â€ she says. â€œThatâ€™s what makes it hard. Because youâ€™ve bared yourself emotionally to that person and been hurt by them.â€ Roberts says these feelings â€œcan sit with you for a long timeâ€. Annabel has moved on with her life. â€œI can be philosophical about it now,â€ she says. â€œBut it ranks pretty highly in my history of painful personal experiences.â€ Betrayal stories â€œare as old as timeâ€, notes Dr Lucy CMM Jackson, an assistant classics professor at Durham University. Tales such as Euripidesâ€™ Medea, about a womanâ€™s bloody quest for vengeance after her husband abandons her, â€œare so fascinating because they articulate a fearâ€, she says. â€œWe tell stories about betrayal to make sense of it, in the hope that maybe we can avoid it or, if not, be better prepared for it. Ultimately, we come back to the idea of betrayal so often because we do have to trust each other.â€ Medea â€œtakes vengeance because her name has been dragged through the dustâ€, says Jackson. Does she see parallels with Vardyâ€™s attempt to restore her reputation? â€œItâ€™s all quite petty,â€ she says. â€œI donâ€™t get the sense that so much honour has been given up in this modern parallel.â€ Like Medea, Stacy Thunesâ€™ story of betrayal revolves around a duplicitous lover. Thunes, a 61-year-old actor and screenwriter from London, was betrayed by her close friend Billie in the early 80s. When Thunes fell in love with a handsome musician, she arranged for the three of them to go for breakfast. At breakfast, to Thunesâ€™ horror, â€œhis foot was actually touching hers under the tableâ€, she says. That evening, Thunes went to Billieâ€™s apartment. The lights were off and Billie wasnâ€™t answering the doorbell. Thunes climbed in through an open window. Billie emerged from her bedroom. â€œI knew by the look on her face that he was there,â€ Thunes says. Being betrayed by Billie, she says, was more painful than being betrayed by her boyfriend. â€œIt made me feel like we were never really friends,â€ says Thunes. â€œLike the friendship meant nothing. All those years of feeling that she had my back were gone in an instant.â€ Those who are betrayed often feel shame, says Roberts. â€œPeople feel embarrassed. They think: how could I have opened myself up to this person and let them do this to me? How could I have been so naive?â€ Lisa, a disability support worker, knows this feeling well. â€œI couldnâ€™t believe how stupid weâ€™d been,â€ she sighs. Lisa met Anna in the 1990s when they worked in adjacent shops in Edinburgh. â€œShe was funny and kind and generous,â€ says Lisa. â€œYou knew where you stood with her. I liked that.â€ When Lisa and her then-husband moved to a small village on the east coast of Scotland, Anna soon followed with her young son. Lisa helped out with childcare and even acted as a guarantor on her rental property. â€œShe was my family and I was hers,â€ says Lisa. But everything fell apart when Annaâ€™s landlord got in touch. Anna had fallen behind on the rent. Lisa offered to lend her Â£1,500, the last of a small legacy her grandfather had left her. â€œShe initially said no, but eventually agreed,â€ says Lisa. â€œI gave her the money in cash. And that was the last time I ever saw her.â€ Eventually, Lisa pieced together the story: Anna had used her money to run away with a boyfriend. â€œI felt more angry at myself than at her, for being so naive,â€ Lisa says. Anna later wrote a letter to Lisa, apologising for hurting her â€“ but not for taking the money. â€œShe said it was my fault, because I forced her to do it,â€ says Lisa. Not everyone will get the closure that comes with an apology, however half-hearted. Cormac and Duncan met a decade ago as teachers at the same school. They became friends quickly and Cormac introduced Duncan to his social and professional circles. When a management post became available, Cormac asked Duncan if he planned to apply for it. â€œHe said no,â€ Cormac says. â€œI would have had no problem if heâ€™d said yes.â€ Cormac spent weeks going over his interview strategy with Duncan. At his interview, he was stunned to see Duncan there, in a suit and tie. â€œHeâ€™d gleaned all the information from me and heâ€™d used me to lay the groundwork for getting to know everyone on the panel,â€ says Cormac. Duncan got the job. â€œI was in tears, because I knew Iâ€™d been dealing with someone very clever and manipulative and careful, and it was devastating.â€ To make matters more maddening, Duncan not only never apologised, but also spread false rumours about Cormac around the school. â€œI had to find my own resolution,â€ says Cormac. â€œI canâ€™t let him live in my head rent-free. I told myself: â€˜That is in the past and everything from here on out will be good.â€™â€ Cormac ended up moving to a different school. â€œI wanted to draw a line under it,â€ he says. Betrayal usually means the end of a friendship. â€œThat urge to withdraw is a protective response,â€ says Freyd. â€œYou donâ€™t want to continue to be betrayed. Itâ€™s analogous to a fight-or-flight response.â€ After Billie wrote to beg for forgiveness, Thunes let her back into her life, but she never trusted her again. â€œEvery time I was with someone, I knew she might have her eye on them,â€ says Thunes. It is possible to rebuild the relationship â€œif youâ€™re both invested in itâ€, says Roberts. â€œCheck in with each other: how does this feel? But the trust may never come back. Accepting that can be a good step.â€ If you feel unable to trust your friend, walk away. â€œYou donâ€™t have to put yourself through it,â€ she says. â€œSome things canâ€™t be repaired, and itâ€™s OK to acknowledge that.â€ Surprisingly few of the betrayed wish harm upon their betrayers. They would rather let go of the hurt and move on. â€œI couldnâ€™t let it drive me mad,â€ says Annabel. â€œI had to carry on doing my thing.â€ But all of them are more careful now; more tentative about who they let in, more thoughtful about what they do with the trust that others place in them. â€œI am reminded of it daily, not because I want to make myself feel bad, but because I donâ€™t want to be that person to hurt other people,â€ says Thunes. But the act of continuing to trust after being hurt so badly is a form of resistance in itself. They will not stop connecting with others, because to close off from the world is to let their betrayers win. Lisa says she would lend Anna the money again in a heartbeat, even knowing everything she does now. â€œIâ€™ve had so much kindness shown to me over the years, too,â€ she says. â€œThatâ€™s what makes life beautiful.â€ Some names have been changed
column4: â€˜Some things canâ€™t be repairedâ€™: how do you recover when a friend betrays you?

column2: The repeal of federally protected abortion rights would result in an increase in violence experienced by Indigenous women, girls and all those who birth, predicted the director of one of the leading research institutes on Indigenous and Alaska Native people across the US. â€œThe only option we have right now if this was to be overturned, is to provide the limited resources and support, but it will be limited, especially initially. As a direct result our people are going to suffer,â€ Abigail Echo-Hawk, director of the Urban Indian Health Institute, told the Guardian. Her remarks followed a leaked supreme court draft opinion authored by Justice Samuel Alito that showed the countryâ€™s highest court ready to overturn Roe v Wade, the nearly 50-year-old ruling protecting the right to an abortion until a fetus is viable outside the womb. Should that decision become official, 13 states with trigger laws would immediately in effect outlaw abortions. Many other Republican-controlled states are expected to follow suit. A 2016 National Institute of Justice study found that more than one in three Indigenous and Alaska Native women had experienced violence in the past year, including sexual violence and violence by an intimate partner. They were 1.7 times more likely than white women to be the victims of violence. They are also at an especially high risk for being trafficked, although comprehensive data is limited. The high rates of these crimes â€“ many of which are never reported, probably due to a mistrust in law enforcement â€“ compounded with not being able to access legal abortions, can leave Indigenous people at an increased risk, explained Echo-Hawk. For those in an abusive relationship, not having access to an abortion could force the victim to stay in a bad situation and lead to more violence, she said. Those being trafficked, some of whom are not allowed to use birth control, may face additional violence from their perpetrators should they become pregnant. Indigenous and Alaska Native women along with Black women are also two to three times more likely to die as a result of their pregnancy than white women, according to the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). Echo-Hawk said having to access unsafe abortions or experiencing the mental anguish of being forced to go through a pregnancy could increase these numbers. â€œThat mental health and the mental violence which weâ€™re experiencing, that has a direct impact on a personâ€™s body when they are going through pregnancy, and it can directly result in pre-term birth and maternal mortality as a direct result,â€ she said. â€œSo, weâ€™re actually battling mental violence that continues to be perpetuated against us.â€ For decades Indigenous people were subjected to forced sterilization in the US, with the practice peaking in the mid-20th century. Repealing Roe v Wade would shift the scales of their reproductive autonomy â€“ or lack thereof â€“ to a new and dire extreme, explained Kerri Colfer, senior Native affairs adviser for the National Indigenous Womenâ€™s Resource Center. â€œNative people are still dealing with the trauma of colonization, historic violence against Native people, forced sterilizations, Indian child removal and boarding schools â€¦ being forced to carry pregnancy is a really traumatic thing, whether that is a pregnancy that resulted from assault or not. And now weâ€™ll have another generation with that trauma to carry on,â€ she said. The Indian Health Service provides health care to about 2.6 million Indigenous and Alaska Natives. But the agency, which is within the US Department of Health and Human Services, restricts abortions to those in which a motherâ€™s life is at risk or in cases of rape or incest that have been reported within 60 days. Echo-Hawk, who was an author of an amicus brief submitted to the supreme court on this issue last year, said as part of that effort, her organization looked at 33 IHS-funded facilities. They found that between 2002 and 2021, only seven Indigenous women were documented as visiting an IHS facility for an abortion. Instead, some Indigenous people seek abortions outside these facilities, she explained. Repealing Roe v Wade would mean that Indigenous people, some of whom live in extremely rural and poverty-stricken areas, might have to travel much further, to facilities outside their state. She asked: â€œHow are we going to afford that travel?â€ Since 2014, Indigenous Women Rising, an Indigenous-led and -centered reproductive justice organization, has helped hundreds through its abortion fund by contributing funding for the procedure, as well as for gas, hotels and childcare. Rachael Lorenzo, its executive director, said if Roe v Wade is overturned, they will need to keep close track of the abortion policies in the states they serve the most, including North Dakota, South Dakota, Arizona and Oklahoma, and willprobably need more funds. The organization has several fundraising events scheduled, including a barbecue cookout for rural communities in southern New Mexico and a two-stepping fundraiser. â€œPeople are scared, and theyâ€™re angry, and theyâ€™re frustrated. And so am I,â€ said Lorenzo, a descendant of Mescalero Apache, Laguna Pueblo and Xicana. â€œBut we also deserve joy. And if thereâ€™s any way we can merge the two, by taking action and not letting ourselves get consumed with how scary this is â€¦ thatâ€™s really where our energy is going to be.â€
column4: Indigenous and Alaska Native women could face escalated violence if Roe is repealed

column2: The outgoing head of Australiaâ€™s offshore oil and gas regulator has helped hand out awards to fossil fuel companies, including Santos, Inpex and Beach Energy, prompting criticism the body could be seen as â€œtoo closeâ€ to industry. He had no role in the selection of the award winners.â€ The spokesperson said Smithâ€™s attendance, which was paid for by Nopsema, was â€œnot unusualâ€ and that the regulator â€œdoes not accept invitations to events from individual titleholders or companiesâ€. column2: Tackling rising food and fuel bills will not add to inflation and people who are â€œthe hardest hitâ€ need help now, the head of the UKâ€™s biggest business association has warned. column2: Amazon has invested more than Â£1bn on TV, movie and live sport content in the UK in recent years and plans to increase spending to make it a must-have streaming service for cash-strapped households. It is the first time that Amazon has revealed the level of investment in Prime Video in the UK, spanning the period since 2018, as competition for viewers intensifies amid a mounting cost of living crisis. While Amazonâ€™s annual UK budget lags that of the $1bn (Â£810m) spent by Netflix on hits from Bridgerton to Sex Education, it continues to rapidly grow â€“ with big releases in the pipeline such as the Lord of the Rings series â€“ while its rival is in the process of cutting budgets and staff after reporting its first fall in subscribers in a decade. â€œOur investments are ramping year over year, said Chris Bird, managing director of Prime Video UK, ahead of the unveiling of a major slate of new programming at an event in central London on Thursday. â€œOver the last five years we have crossed the Â£1bn mark, that feels like a milestone to recognise our growth here. We are fully committed to our future in the UK, as we are across Europe and the world.â€ Amazon has doubled down on its commitment to the UK signing a record-breaking long lease deal for its first permanent studio space in the UK at Shepperton Studios, where Netflix also has a deal, and making the surprise decision to move shooting of the mega-budget Lord of the Rings TV series from New Zealand to the UK. New Zealandâ€™s minister for economic development and tourism, Stuart Nash, said that the first series in the saga, called The Rings of Power, which will premiere later this year, cost about NZ$650m (Â£332m) to make. Bird acknowledged that the streaming market is not immune to the cost of living crisis, but maintained that Prime Video has achieved the status of a â€œmust haveâ€ service alongside Netflix. â€œWe are expecting a challenging time [for households] ahead,â€ he said. â€œInflation is rising, the cost of living is soaring and we donâ€™t expect the same level of video engagement from customers as we had seen through the pandemic period. But that is not dampening investment at all. We are not expecting a dramatic slowdown. We are still seeing growth in our business and customers are pleased and excited.â€ At the end of the first quarter Netflix had 222m global subscribers, Prime Video 152m and Disney+ 138m. In the UK, Netflix remains the market leader with an estimated 14m subscribers, followed by Prime Video on 11.9m and Disney+ at 4.8m, according to Ampere Analysis. â€œWe expect customers will be more savvy in their purchase choices,â€ he said. â€œItâ€™s been about multiple subscriptions in the past, but with the challenges of the cost of living perhaps that reduces.â€ As well as its own subscription video-on-demand service Amazon has an advertising-funded free service called Freevee, which was rebranded from IMDB TV last month, and 100,000 titles to buy or rent as well as offering subscriptions to partner video channels such as reality TV streamer Hayu. Netflix has said that it is to launch an ad-funded subscription tier later this year to attempt to reignite growth. â€œWe are a different service,â€ said Bird, who worked at British streaming site LoveFilm, which was bought by Amazon in a Â£200m deal in 2011 to spur its ambitions to take on Netflix in the UK. â€œOur catalogue, whilst perhaps smaller in volume than other services, is very well crafted and specific in our goal to be seen as high quality.â€ While US streamers including Amazon, Netflix and Disney continue to inject an increasing amount of money into British-made shows and films, the biggest spenders in the UK remain traditional national broadcasters. The BBCâ€™s total annual content budget across TV, radio and online is about Â£2.3bn, with spend on TV content about Â£1.6bn of this. ITV spends about Â£1.1bn annually on content for its portfolio of channels, while Channel 4â€™s Â£700m budget is about the same as Netflix. column2: The Australian Electoral Commission concedes a large number of Australians â€“ possibly in excess of 100,000 people â€“ who tested positive for Covid early this week and will be isolating on Saturday may not be able to vote in the federal election.
